title: badBrick - Case for Arduino UNO and Adafruit WAV Shield.

description.text: .STLs Fixed.. Good To go. Fits 1 (one) Arduino UNO R3 with an Adafruit WAV shield, in a compact lego compatible mount Brick. "Like US" https://www.facebook.com/badbrick The case itself can be stand alone or mounted. The (4) holes also fit the Lego round shafts in technic kits. Its also designed so that you can attach jumper wires throught the top to connect up something else. If you don't have a 3D printer but you're interested in getting one of these we can print you one at www.badbrick.com/catalog

In MakerWare, I modify the "Medium" settings:
Quality: Layer Height = 0.2 and I increase the temp to 240C to let the little larger prints fuse better. All other defaults are the same.

description.text:
3D printed, 608 full spec, planetary gear bearing. The 608 is also known as skateboard bearings. Good for prototyping (before using real 608 bearings) and for light load jobs.

Specs:

  • 19-teeth sun
  • 31-teeth annulus or ring gear
  • 10 6-teeth planets
  • 0.15 tolerance

As per 608 specs:

  • 22 mm diameter
  • 7 mm thickness
  • 8 mm bore .

3 different 608 bearings:

  • round outer race and inner bore (typical 608)
  • square outer race (22 mm) and inner (6 mm) bore
  • hex outer race (22 mm) and inner (8 mm) bore

Square and hex break-in tools:

  • outer race holder
  • inner bore key, with triangular shaft for a drill's 3-jaw chuck and a hole for a pencil or screwdriver to give you extra leverage.

I give credit to Gear God emmett, I used his customizer to spec it to 608. His branding had to go though, it had a few holes.

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=53451

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.095 mm

Infill:

0%

Notes:

Printed in a SeeMeCNC Rostock Max V2 with E3D V6:

  • 0.25 mm nozzle hot end
  • 0.095 layer height
  • ~2 hours
  • ABS though it should be printed with nylon for the best performance

Somebody printed it with .4 mm nozzle, which is good as most OEM nozzles can print it and faster.

Since it sliced to 74 layers, I set it up with 37 top and 37 bottom solid layers, 0% infill, and only 1 perimeter; it's solid.

Lapping (smoothing the parts that contact)

Lapping with a drill, using the included tools, makes it smoother, it gets warm but I think it helps. I lapped it for 2 seconds with the drill AND coarse abrasive compound, and it is now very smooth, though coarse abrasive may be too much as it introduced more axial play; will test fine abrasive compound.

Depending on the application, a little bit of lithium grease could work? Will test this, too.

You need to free the gears, but it does turn, though it is rough. Could be broke-in better with the tools included. A tool for the round bearing is in the works.

Customized using the following options:

w = 7
P = 45
T = 7
D = 22
tol = 0.15
number_of_teeth_on_planets = 6
approximate_number_of_teeth_on_sun = 20
nTwist = 1
number_of_planets = 10

comments.text: It's a great idea! Tho it requires a considerable amount of force to break it, because of the many contact points in the herringbone teeth. I'm not sure how "cuttable" or "breakable" wings might hold, without making them so strong that you would have to grind it or cut it in a way that may damage the design. I would think the hex 608 would be the best compromise, and presumably you could break it with the part you designed for it.

This is the result of a 3D Scan I performed using 123D Catch from Autodesk. It is of a tree stump I found while in a park.

This is a good print to use to test various angles, flat surfaces and resolution. Feel free to print at various resolutions and infill settings.

Let me know what you think and if you would like more scans uploaded!

I found 20% infill to be the best to avoid any holes in the flat areas of the stump. This print should print fine without support material.

My print was done on a Powerspec 3D Pro using ABS. Sliced in makerware.

title: The talking head of Stephen Colbert

description.text:
The Talking Head - Stephen Colbert Edition 
Have you ever wanted Stephen Colbert to personally read you the News?  Spread the truthiness from a place of honor at your very own kitchen table?  Well now he can.  
Last seen Closing the Colbert Show!

1) Print all parts
2) Add an 8mm rod through the pivot point in the mouth. The rod should extend about 5mm beyond each side of the part.
3) Assemble the left and right halves of the head, Use short segments of 3mm filament pressed into the provided holes to assemble. Some drilling may be required to restore the holes to their appropriate size.
4) Set the mouth in the hole on the left side of the head
5) Glue a servo to the interior of the left side of the head, any servo will work, but smaller will give you more space to work with.
6) Run a piece of ridged wire between the servo horn and the lever arm on the back of the mouth so that when the servo moves, the mouth opens and closes.
7) Upload the talking head software to the Arduino and attach it and its battery to the inside of the head. Make the electrical connections as described in the diagram.
8) Thread the audio input cable through the hole in the back of the head.
9) Press the Right and Left halfs together, making sure the mouth can move freely
10) Use a headphone splitter to hook the head and a set of self powered speakers up to an audio source.
11) Find Stephen Colbert sound board and use it to make the head talk.
Notes:
The lip-syncing works best with the volume turned up as loud as possible.

description.text:
I simply added belt grip on the other side. I haven't tested it yet. But I don't see why it can't work though. My printer is tied up at the moment. Update: Tested. I tweaked the bottom teeth grooves to have better grip since the bottom layer is often squished for better adhesion. I deleted the other sizes since 5mm seems to the best for size and strength. You can tweak it to your needs. :D Default setting:
belt_pitch = 2;
belt_width = 10;
belt_offset = 0; // Use for Prusa I2 X-Carriage
clamp_height = 5;
clamp_width = 10;
clamp_length = 18; // distance between the center of the 2 holes
tooth_width = 1.3;
tooth_heigth = .75;
bottom_tooth_width = 1.4;
bottom_tooth_height = 1.2;
offset = belt_pitch/4;
offset2 = offset+(belt_pitch/2);

This is my idea of a cheap and sustainable power plant to be anchored somewhere in the open ocean and exposed to the waves there.

Principle

The three satellites form a tripod system which oscillates against the center body as waves travel through the arrangement. The center body is guided passively by the linkage to roll into a position where the piston can freely oscillate within the hydraulic cylinder. This forces are comparatively small.
A pelton or francis turbine placed within the center body (where there is lots of space for all sorts of equipment) will convert the hydraulic pressure into electric energy.

In practice each of the bodies will be fabricated to have a density of 0.5, so that it is half submerged. The mass of the main body should be equivalent to the sum of the masses of the satellite bodies.

Energy harvest

To give you some idea about the amount of energy the system can produce with a main body radius of, say, 10 meters:

  1. A radius of 10 meters gives the center ball a volume of 4200 m³ while the satellites will have a radius of 7 m. So the total mass of all four bodies will be 4200 tons.
  2. If waves oscillate the satellite masses against the center mass at an amplitude of only 2 meters with a half period of 2.5 s (= wave period of 5s) the piston will produce a hydraulic power of 33 MW.
  3. Say, we can harvest half of it as electric power, isn't that a lot?
  4. The system will be able to withstand monster waves up to 20 m. For bigger waves (like Tsunamis), it will have to flood its air chambers with water to increase its density > 1 and dive to the sea ground.

Better think big

Unfortunately, it is almost hopeless to produce energy with a printed 3D model of say R = 5cm, at an amplitude of 5cm. My calculation routine (which is part of the code) shows that at a period 1/s the hydraulic energy will be 0.5 Watt, which might not even be enough to press out a little fountain on top of the piston linkage, unless piston, seal and cylinder are fabbed with high precision.

Code

Better scale the thing as a whole. Didn't take much care on parametrizing everything. But I put many comments to guide you through the easy and straight forward code. For faster coding I used my library shortcuts.scad. Sorry for that, but it is so handy ...

To get a printed model of the system, I would suggest to print the balls hollow and fill them half with wax. When pouring in the wax, it should be swapped around to get the walls easily watertight.

The linkage is best made of bicyle spokes (2mm). Printing it is not advisable. All other parts are provided as STLs

description.text:
As an exercise, I designed a robotic gripper without consulting the internet or other samples for reference. I think it came out pretty well!

This is intended to be used with:

  • 1" pvc pipe
    (can be adjusted with Shaftdiameter)
  • 4-40 screws and nuts (jam nuts recommended)
    (can be adjusted with screw_diameter and nut_diameter)
  • springs or rubber bands
  • wire or string through the pipe as an actuator

Note that the handle and trigger are printed as one piece, as there would be no way to assemble it otherwise.

My intent was to use flexible filament for the gripper ends, but I haven't gotten around to it yet.
The solution to join to two cylider easily and quickly.

description.text:
What you see in front of you here is a hybrid of a yacht and cargo ship. The design was made so that it can maximize the amount of weight it can carry. A full video is made based on this experiment.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jp74nWON5R0

The beauty of this model is that it can be 3d printed using relatively small desktop 3d printers. Being called the “Triple Float Yacht” you may think it must be assembled, ironically the design allows it to be printed all at once. No support material is required to have this boat printed. It was printed using a 3% infill.

The design of the 2 smaller pontoons on the side and the large pontoon carrying the deck provides the boat with an outstanding ability to balance out itself. They stabilize the boat since it is stretched outwards covering more surface area but maintaining the weight concentration in the middle. The idea of this is to prevent the boat from rocking left to right when it is in more aggressive waters.

The design of a door was cleverly made in the model without having the need to cut a hole in it. One piece of the side panels were made extremely thin so that the printer will not be able to print it out. This can be done by setting the settings of the printer as shown in the video. The printer will skip that area and leave a hole or in other words our door. Using this technique will prevent uneven surfaces when modeling. An extra millimeter of a cut will leave a dipped down surface in the large pontoon.

The Triple Float Yacht is able to carry over double the weight of its own. In the video the numbers state that it can only hold 38 quarters, but if you examine carefully at the end some quarters were placed without the count meter actually moving. That means the boat was actually able to carry just over 40 Canadian quarters.

This is my entry for the #MakeItFloat contest!

This model can be 3d Printed using the following temperatures:

  • Print Head (At least 200˚C)

  • Print Bed 75˚C

  • This very model was printed in PLA filament

  • 3% fill density

More information can be seen in the video.

title: PRUSA I3 - Universal Belt Tie - Clip de courroie universel

description.text:
This simple and universal Belt Tie will not open, no matter the tension of the belt, because it is not directly locking the belt, but just maintaining the belt in such a position that the belt self locks.

I used it for the X axis 6mm belt of my PRUSA I3.

It can be helpful for many others printers and applications in which the same kind of belt is used, whatever is the pitch.

Design is so simple that the 2 Belt Ties I printed went directly from the hotbed to each end of the belt of the X carriage, without any need for finishing process.

The file originally made with SKETCHUP is also attached for eventual adaptations, especially for different sizes of belt.

====================

Avec cette agraphe simple et universelle, peu importe la tension de la courroie, l'agraphe ne s'ouvrira pas car l'agraphe ne fait que maintenir la courroie dans une position où cette dernière se bloque elle-même.

Je l'ai utilisée pour le verrouillage de la courroie (6mm) de l'axe des X de ma PRUSA I3.

L'agraphe peut être employée sur de nombreuses autres imprimantes et applications utilisant le même type de courroie, quel que soit leur pas.

Le dessin est si simple que les 2 agraphes que j'ai imprimé sont passées directement de la plaque chauffante à la fixation de chacune des extrémités de la courroie, sans besoin d'aucune finition.

Le fichier de SKETCHUP est également joint, en cas de souhait d'adaptation, notamment pour d'autres tailles de courroie.

title: 2010+ Ford Taurus Key Fob (shrunken, no buttons)

description.text: I was always bothered by the immense size of the key fob for my 2012 Taurus, which included so many unnecessary features like buttons and a mechanical key.  I wanted something small, light, and waterproof to take with me when I do outdoors stuff.

I printed an upper and lower container into which I installed the guts from the factory key fob.  I superglued the two halves together, then applied a few coats of Krylon Fusion Black Gloss, and then a few coats of clear acrylic sealant.  I hope that has made it waterproof - but when the battery goes dead I'll have to crack the case open w/pliers.

title: Multi Hook for keys, based on Triple Switch 7 Hooks by cramsay1

description.text:
7 hooks with no switch holes which I needed for holding paint brushes.
multi_hook.stl is a WIP which has the switches cut off, but with sort of an open ended top.

Cramsay1 or others may modify and fix it up, although I did think of another way to do it.

I imported Triple Switch 7 into Blender, then placed a cube over the parts I didn't want, resized it, and used the Boolean modifier (Difference) which removed the parts of the switch plate that I didn't want.

title: LM8UU Linear Bush
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Inspired by the "Self Centering Bush" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:91390.
Another style of printable bush bearing to replace the noisy LM8UU linear ball bearing type. Great when printed with nylon filament : http://www.taulman3d.com/ http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

Depending on printer calibration this could be a loose or tight fit, such are the fine tolerances required for bearings.   
However if it is tight, you can run the bearing up and down an 8mm drill or threaded bar, or if it is too loose you can gently (emphasis) heat this with a gas lighter to make the vanes slightly pliable, and lightly lever a vane or three with a small screwdriver to adjust tightness.

comments.text: Hi, I actually think the IGUS bearings are a little loose for my liking. I have the usual set-up of using 3 bearings on two parallel 8mm smooth rods, two on one rod and one on the other. I actually got a little play, sufficient enough to create a bit of a skew when changing direction either X+ to X- or Y+ to Y-. This is noticeable when printing a circle and I got little flats at the extreme x or y of the circumference. This thing can be printed tight and opened out with a drill or threaded rod until the desired fit is achieved. Another option is the following self centring bush of mine : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:97041http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...

title: Self Centering Bush
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed this as a diameter reducer for a friend's telescope. The idea was to produce a self centering bush that will convert Dia 2" to Dia 1.25".
Both diameters are purposly printed tight which allows the flexible vanes to compress and apply an even self centering force all around the bore/shaft. Important in the telescope world to keep things centred and collimated. Could also be an airless tyre design (for RC) if printed with a flexible filament Suitable for use as a tolerance ring. http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

There is a slight lead in taper on the vane ends to aid a push fit assembly.  
Feel free to adapt, OpenSCAD or "customise" this idea for other diameters and applications.  
Scale up X and Y for a bangle / bracelet!!!  
EDIT 01/05/13: Tweeked the diameters by 0.2mm to increase the tightness. Changed length to 30mm.

comments.text: or scale it down for an engagement ring- It will save you thousands!!!

title: More Micro Polyhedron Vertices
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a generalization of Micro Polyhedron Vertices to arbitrary number of edges per face, like Polyhedron Facets. I also reduced the clearance to suit my printer better.

Faces with 3-6 edges are supplied as stl. Different order of male/female edges (connectors) is indicated with alphabetical suffix. If the provided stl's are not enough, dig into the scad file (or just tell me). The scad also contains code to generate round centers, like the Polyhedron Facets, for a more organic appearance. For possible combinations of faces, see for example Archimedean_solid on wikipedia. The provided photo is of an icosidodecahedron and a cuboctahedron.

author: triple-e

description.text: This is my entry for the #MakeItFloat challenge. I named it "Balloon Boy" for pretty obvious reasons. It uses 3 stabilizers that are printed at 0% infill (hollow) at 0.1 mm layer height. The boat itself is also printed in this fashion. The balloons I used were simple water balloons. I used 5 pumps of air from my manual balloon pump, however, you will most likely use a different pump, so experiment with different values. It can hold about 50-60 pennies depending on the # of pumps on the balloons.

How to Put Together your Very Own "Balloon Boy" Boat

  1. Print the "Balloon_Boy.stl" file along with the "Balloon Boy Stablizer V2" files (3 stabilizers) at 0.1 mm layer height and 0% infill for both files

  2. Use your glue of choice (I used super glue) to place the stabilizers in a || shape on the bottom of the boat (the is the back of the boat).

  3. Pump up 8 balloons and put the ends through the holes on the sides of the boat with the knot pulled all the way through.

  4. Get a water source and try it out!

author: Jordanomaxwell01

title: Spool Holder for the Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text:
This is a remix of emmett's Printrbot Spool Holder.

Main changes include:
• A more acute guide arm angle
• Threaded spool rod with an adjustable collar for securing different spool sizes
• A more refined aesthetic and form language

This part was an opportunity for me to practice some applied structural design and solid modeling so it might be a bit over-engineered for its purpose. Feedback is welcome and encouraged.

• Printed using Gun Metal and Yellow PLA supplied by Printrbot
  • Both the base and threaded collar will fit on a 6x6 bed
  • 0% fill for the collar, 100% for the base
  • .2mm layer height
  • No support material required

Note: The collar's purpose is to keep the spool secure and on axis. If overtightened the spool will not rotate. Mind this when screwing on the collar. I am working on a future version that will include a bearing to enable a free-rotating design.

Note: I found scaling the collar up to 1.07% allows for smooth engagement of the threaded collar. This scale factor might vary based on your printer and resolution. I would recommend somewhere in the high range of 1/100 for sure measure.

description.text:
This is a 3D printed Light Saber I designed as a personal project to keep myself occupied and to submit it in the #lightitup challenge
​
​Here's a demo video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mhZpyn2MeaM&feature=youtu.be
​
​Let me start off by saying this is a very easy print/make... The handle only has two main prints and you have the option of printing either 6 individual sliding cylinders or print one with all of them already embedded... Every print can be printed on a single extruder, no print requires any supports, and the tallest print is 155mm high on the Z axis... So as long as your printer can print 155 in the Z, you can make this no problem...
​
​The only thing you will need to buy is this LED light and remote for $10....
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00FS7N0J8?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00
​
​I used Bendlay filament for the cylinders mostly because it lets a lot of light pass through is (91%) and it is also a lot stronger than PLA... It is pretty expensive, but totally worth it for this project... If you desire, you can also print the cylinders in natural PLA/ABS or any translucent filament you want to use... However, you wont get the same glow you get with Bendlay... Here's a link to Bendlay...
http://www.matterhackers.com/store/3d-printer-filament/175mm-bendlay-threequarter-kg
​
Here's an Instructables I made on the details on how to make the light saber...
http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-LED-LIGHTSABER/

​Here is an instructional video I made that basically goes over everything that I'll go over in this Instructable...
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vF8YRznobKc

Here's the Instructables I made for this... Everything you need to know is there...
http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-LED-LIGHTSABER/

title: Diamond Hotend Mount and BasePlate for the Rigidbot 3D Printer

description.text:
Rigidbot Extruder Plate and Mount for the Diamond Hotend.

Technically I haven't finished my Diamond install, but the plate and mount are solid at this point. I'll post more pictures once I complete the install and have my Diamond up and running.

This extruder mount is designed in two sections (Plate & Mount) so that it can be printed without "supports", the only caveat is the Mount needs to be printed upside down.

The Plate has a hole for a proximity sensor.

It has two sets of holes for the X-Axis GT2 Belt Adapter, one for 32T pulley and the other for 16T pulley.

You'll need a couple M3 screws;
2x M3 x 10mm
1x M3 x 10mm with a counter-sunk head (bearing holder mounts over same location)

So that I could swap extruders easily I stole the linear bearing holders from my Y-Axis (heated bed) and printed replacement holders for the Y-Axis. Reason being . . . stock Rigidbot Bearing Holders snap off the LM8UU's easily and I want to use several different extruder plates. Bearing holder downloadable here as as well.

author: Mykal451

description.text:
I've recently changed out my Gen6 Deluxe to a Megatronics v2 board.  
I have designed this case to mount the board to the Orca.  
The DRV8825 stepper controllers allow 32x microstepping, the original steps/mm must be multiplied by 4 if using this.  
Things to note - the end-stops need to be replaced with 3-wire versions. (+, -, Signal), and that the original connectiors cannot be used for them (the original opto-connectors take up 2x5 pins, instead of 1x3, hope this makes sense.)  
The original 4-pin motor connectors will fit and do work. There should be space in the case to fit these.  
The endstops need to be inverted in the firmware, and the #define MANUAL_HOME_POSITIONS  needs to be set.  
The stepper reference voltage for the SY42STH47-1684B motors should be 0.84V. This sets the maximum current for the windings at 1.68 Amps. The reference point is the tiny dot to the right of the potentiometer and the two capacitors, shown in the picture.  
UPDATE - have modified parts, hinge should now work. :)

Print and use 2x M3 screws to secure base to hinged lid.  
Use printed spacers, to space board off of printer, allowing cabling to be routed behind the case.

description.text:
I designed this to work with some leftover 8mm rods and 608 skate bearings I had. One set is for smaller diameter spools (specifically measured for Taulman spools) and the other is for more standard diameter spools (specifically for Push Plastic). Ideally, these two can sit next to each other using the same pair of rods. Should make it easy to switch between the two sizes of filament spools. Spool width is adjustable along the 8mm rods as well.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6ZtAxlMDrIk

FilamentChallenge

You will need a printing width of about 170mm to print this part.

Make two of each part. No supports needed if printed flat on its side. I printed mine at 30%-40% infill with 3 perimeters.

Supply your own 8mm rods/dowels and 608 skate bearings.
Solidoodle upgraded Idler pulley brackets for 5x8x2.5 bearings. Use original hardware and just add a set screw to the pulley.

description.text:
I scanned a Roman Imperial silver coin from my coin collection using a Roland Active Piezo Sensor 3D scanner. 
After some digital massage I thought it fun to make a replica 4x the size in black ABS on a Roland MDX-540S-ATC CNC mill.

The model has only the surfaces scannable by a contact force poky-type scanner, as 2 shells opposing each other, therefore the geometry needs some work before printing on a 3D printer.. I think it'd be really worth it, however.

comments.text:
I really like your work, very well made. I've got a ton of coins I would like to do this way.
What softwares did you use to get to the final result in your hand there?
keep up the good work!
comments.author: FilipDeCooman

comments.text: The scan was done on a Roland MDX40 with the ZSC-1 scanning probe. The software is Roland Dr Picza, which outputs .STL files. The resulting mesh was prepared in the open-source meshlab, then edited somewhat with Rhino3D. A complete closed manifold should be straightforward to make, though with the software I had, somewhat laborious. To mill the part in ABS the 2 opposing shells were sufficient to drive 3-axis toolpath generation in VisualMill and post-processing into Roland NC code (Gcode for Roland mills).

description.text: I was experiencing z-wobble with the existing coupler on the printrbot simple so I designed my own.  I have yet to test it, but it should work.  This is shorter than the original printrbot coupling, so should not interfere with y-axis motor.

the tube used to make the flexible coupler on the Simple is taken off the screw and inserted into the smaller side of the coupler.  The lead screw is then inserted into the other end.  The whole coupler is secured using 4 M3 x 20 screws and 4 M3 nuts.  In order for the extruder to come into contact with the bed, longer springs need to be used along with 4 M3 X 30 screws.  If you don't have longer springs, simply print up some M3 spacers.

description.text:
These are Eagle v6.4.0 layout and pdf files for creating a PCB heatbed for the printrbot jr. The heatbed is mounted under a aluminum plate (see here) that acts as the printring platform.
In the PCB heatbed center is a little hole. Through this hole a thermistor is touching the aluminum plate's backside to measure the temperature at the plates center.
The PCB heatbed is cover with "plastik 70" spray for electrical insulation. (For PLA a heatbed temperature of max. 65 °C is needed so the "plastik 70" should not decompose and should therefore be suitable in this application.)
The heatbed and sensor are directly driven by the stock printrbot jr. printrboard. Only a stronger power supply was needed (12V with at least 15A --> P >= 180W).
At the edge and top of the PCB heatbed a power LED with matching series resistor (both SMD) are soldered in place. *) UPDATE #1: After one week of using the heatbed I can say that it works great. I did not flash the new temperature sensor's resistance values to the printrboard. It is close enough to the expected stock temperature sensor's range. If I set 47 °C [117 °F] in my pronterface interface I reproducibly get a surface temperature of 55 °C [131 °F] (measured with this infrared thermometer). *) UPDATE #2: Please remember to drill the holes in the PCB with a much bigger diameter as needed and use washers to compensate the bigger hole size. This is needed since the PCB and aluminum plate have different thermal expansion coefficient and if they were thightly fix to each other, without any play in the drill holes, the resulting stress could crack and/or destroy the whole setup.

Materials:
  • PCB one sided (35 µm Cu, min. size 170 x 125mm) covered with photo resist [e.g. this board]
  • Thermal grease (the one used with computer CPUs)
  • Kapton tape
  • Aluminum plate (170 x 155mm) with mounting holes
  • Plastik 70 spray (isolation layer) [e.g. this one]
  • Thermistor 100kOhm base resistance [e.g. this one]
  • SMD LED with matching resistor for 12V usage
  • Metal connector pins
  • Upgraded power supply (12V and at least 15A) [e.g. this one]

title: FlashForge Creator Pro Back Cable Holder

description.text:
The main middle cable always folded back on me and caused rubbing against the acrylic top on my FF pro.

This is an adapter to keep the cable closer to the back of the printer resulting in a higher arch for less rubbing against the acrylic plastic top cover.

There are two models please refer to instructions tab for more information.

This is the first useful thing I have made and my first upload. I have taken so much from this website I feel the need to give back something I have created.

Please do at your own risk I take no responsibility if something goes wrong.

Print with .2mm at 100% infill. I prefer PLA because ABS version had a bit of flex.

Fat screw print on side with support
Flat screw print on side no support
(I am using Simplify3D for printing)

File the hole a little bit so the screw slides threw on your print. Only a little filing necessary makes it a lot easier.

Remove the screw behind the printer towards the top. This screw helps hold the back plate onto the printer. Replace with the whatever the next length of screw is I think mine is about 2mm or so longer then the original. (it is a pain getting the hex wrench in there and screwing it in so I don't want to take it out and measure)

If you cannot find the same type of screw like I could not I created a use the fat version to use the other type as shown in the picture.

PS. I have not tried the flat screw version as I could not find the original screw but longer at my hardware store.
If someone does try the flat screw version and there is a problem or it needs to be indented in like the fat screw try the fat screw version anyway or let me know I will make a third model.

description.text:
These are pieces for Settlers of Catan. The Settlement can fit under the City for those who make their own rules and want to have 'SuperCities'. The Wall fits around the City. The Metropolis is for Cities and Knights, and is a flag that fits into a hole in the top of the City piece. The road is just a road.

These are the first things I have ever tried to get printed on a 3D printer. The printer I use is at the local library, and it is on the fritz, so none have been printed yet, so I have no idea if they work or how they fit on a board. Regardless of how they turn out, I'll update this to let you know.

I plan on doing a Robber, a Barbarian, Ships and other pieces in the future, once I see how my first few things turn out.

Cheers,
3point14rat

Nothing needs to be done except trim out the bottom cross pieces on the Wall so that it can sit over top of the City.

Since I have yet to get all of them printed, I don't actually know how good these will work on a board during play. Hopefully in a few days I'll get a look at them.

Until then, print at your own risk.

author: CARROLLJ

title: iPhone 5 adapter for handheld illuminated microscope

description.text:
This print aligns the iPhone 5 lens with the eyepiece of a cheap handheld microscope available at Radio Shack (~$15, Model: MM-100 | Catalog #: 63-1313). The design consists of two pieces: a top iPhone adapter that snaps onto a microscope adapter base.
  • I made this a 2 piece design with the intent to create adapters for different types of microscopes and phones.
  • Slots along the left and right allow manipulation of the zoom dial. Base is long enough to remain attached to microscope when at full zoom.
    • So far I've used this to inspect PCB's and entertain/educate my nieces and nephews. Further notes:
  • The iPhone 5 fits pretty snug, but please be careful and pay attention to ensure it does not slip out and shatter.
  • the top iPhone 5 adapter fits snug to the microscope base, but can pop off when manipulating the microscope zoom. I suggest sliding the assembled adapter up, manipulating the zoom, then sliding the assembled adapter back down until the eyepiece comes in contact with the top iPhone 5 adapter.
    • More to come.

I am able to make a fitting adapter using PLA with a Makerbot Replicator 2 using these settings:
Medium quality
10% Infill
2 shells
0.27 layer height
no Raft
no Supports Instructions for use:
  • Remove the rubber end to the eyepiece.
  • Snap iPhone into iPhone adapter top.
  • Connect the top iPhone adapter top to the microscope adapter base.
  • Slide assembled adapter onto microscope until iPhone adapter top comes in contact with the eyepiece. Contact with the eyepiece ensures the best image.
  • Turn on the microscope light bulb.
  • Activate the iPhone camera.
  • When the image comes up, tap the center of the image to focus the iPhone lens.
  • Turn the dial at the base of the microscope to focus until image is clear.
  • Use pinch zoom to manipulate image on phone.
  • Repeat steps 7 and 8 as needed to clear image.

description.text:
Welcome to Novam, a free tool for turning heightmaps and images into 3D .STL files for 3d printers. It also has rendering functionality. Download link: (Windows version)
https://sourceforge.net/projects/novam/files/ Don't mind the trolls. This link is perfectly safe, i would not put my name on anything that spread malware, if you are still in doubt, the program can also be downloaded from this site. If you are a architect, printing out the area around the next big project might become very valuable.
Want a 3-dimensional version of your painting or contact card? perfectly possible!
The options are virtually endless, any image can get that extra dimension! I think this tool is really useful, and everyone with a printer should have access to it, so instead of selling it, i have added a donation link.
This allows the people who are unable to pay access to the tool, and hopefully some kindhearted people are going to donate so i can continue to develop software for the community! Donation link:
https://sites.google.com/site/sccp3d/finan
(This is also the homepage for another printer related project!) This is a early alpha release, bugs will be fixed, functionality will be added, so stay tuned!
Feel free to come with suggestions for new functions, sources will also be released when the project is closer to completion! Cheers!

comments.text:
Is this part meant to be compatible with an E3D V6? I managed to get it on my stock part, until it broke just the other day.

comments.text: No, I designed this with the original extruder the One-Up/Two-Up came with, the Anubis hot-end. But, the E3D and Anubis should both be interchangeable with the Two-Up by default I believe. It could be shrinkage or a slightly less calibrated printer, if its too tight just sand the inside walls where the hot end slides in until it fits. Hope it helps!

comments.text: Hi, sorry for not getting back to you sooner (work has been crazy). I'm using MakerBot Desktop software Version 3.7.0.95. I checked the setting I used, not quick default, I used "Quick" settings; Quality Standard, Raft on, Supports off, Layer Height 0.20mm, infill 30%, Number of Shells 4, Material is MakerBot PLA, Extruder Temperature 215 Degrees C. All other settings are defaults, maybe try resetting defaults and then print with those settings, I find that removing the prints from the raft as soon as the print finishes is best. I use a pair of pointy nose pliers to help remove the raft.

title: 360 Panoramic Motorised Programmable Tripod Head for DSLR

description.text:
UPDATE: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:827134 An easy-ish conversion for the manfrotto 3 way head to streamline taking of spherical panoramas. Made 2 so far but still work in progress. About 170 degrees vertical fov with samyang 8mm (corner to corner) Update: page about the project http://dslr360.ilyatitov.com/
Example panoramas: http://ilyatitov.com/360/ See it in action: http://youtu.be/m-kqBCw5f4w
http://youtu.be/QM9lXYVwHF0
http://youtu.be/dYxgKii06uE Key Parts:
Nema 17 motor
Arduino nano
H bridge
Connectors
2 printed gears
1 printed quick release lens clamp
1 printed motor support
cable ties :D This hack is completely reversible, ie you can take everything off and have your panoramic head in its original condition again. The parts are attached with cable ties and hot glue which comes off with a bit of force. More info to follow if anyone is interested This project is a continuation of my iphone panoramic head project (I didn't have a 3d printer then) http://iphone360.ilyatitov.com/

Print as you like, the layer height is not crucial.  
Gears are a tight fit, might need a bit of filing to get them on.  
The lens holder is rotated to minimise wasted plastic on support material, don't forget to enable it!

comments.text: Awesome project.  I would really like to make one of my own.  I have a few questions before I get started to make sure that I am not wasting my time.  I don't have a large budget.
comments.author: johnreskusich

comments.text: You get what yo pay for with tripods, manfrotto tripods are perfect if you want to make it rotate with a motor. The head mount is 6cm in diameter and it is the same on a tripod I've had since 2007 and the one I picked up in the airport going on a break. The large gear fits around it perfectly with a bit of bashing and stays on without any glue. And the tripods are nice and sturdy. The head is a 3 way standard head that had 2 knobs replaced with screws.
comments.author: johnreskusich

comments.text: What Samyang lens?  14?
comments.author: TomB19

comments.text: Big fan of how the mount holds the lens as close to the end as possible to minimize any skew introduced by the length of the lens.
comments.author: atreidae

comments.text: The last version of the lens mount is designed to position the lens so the axis of rotation matches nodal point of the lens. It can also be adjusted using one of the tilts on the tripod head to get it perfect. (ie put an object in front of the lens and adjust forward tilt until the position of reference object doesn't change in relation to background when camera is rotated from side to side) I get either "good" or "very good" in ptgui optimizer
comments.author: atreidae

comments.text: Very nice project!
comments.author: fma

comments.text: Hey, thanks! Will it be a problem that it has only got one axis? I looked at one of the videos of how your software works with the astronomic mounts, but obviously that doesn't rotate around the nodal point. With a bit of input this can be made into a 2 axis nodal head and then you'll have a nice head you can use with more or less any lens/camera.
It is possible to rotate arround nodal point with astronomic heads, but it needs some mods of the arm with large DSLR...
comments.author: webboggles

description.text:
This is Clyde from Pacman, the orange Ghost.
You can print this object in three colors, even with a monochromatic 3D printer. Infact The design is divided in three main layers.

Start to print with white filament, then, before the printer completes the layer of the eyes, change the filament to blue (or black).
After the eyes are completed, change the filament to orange for Clyde, red for Blinky, light blue for Inky, and pink for Pinky.

A simple box to store small things.
The inner dimensions can be adjusted and the latch on top makes sure that it doesn't open when it shouldn't.

UPDATE: now with the option to add more latches

I printed this thing on an Ultimaker 2 with a layer height of 0.1mm.
The hinges for the lids are designed to be printed in place.
The inner Dimensions can be adjusted via the height, width and length variables.
If the box is very wide you might want to add more latches by using the "latches" variable. But remember that the latches are about 15mm wide.

The display options are there to show the box in different configurations. To use them set the "print" variable to "0". Don't forget to change it back before printing.
The variables "close" and "lock" are there to show the box in the opened and closed positions.

To assemble it just clip the two parts of the latch in place and enjoy your print ;)

description.text:
I designed this coin holder to fit in my car's cup holder. It's a bit awkward, because the arm rest slides over the cup holder when not in use, and all the other coin holders I've seen are too tall.  
The coins sit in the holder at an angle so it's easier to slide them out. Admittedly, this does not hold a ton of coins because it is so short. I was only able to jam 13 quarters in there, but it does the trick if you don't need a bunch of loose change in the car.
I printed this at .15mm with 3 shells. It's held together on the bottom with four screws. The springs, which I CA-glued in the coin pushers, are from McMaster-Carr, item number 9657K414.

I really liked the knob that owens made for the Z axis on the Printrbot Simple. When I downloaded his part, I discovered the hole didn't go all the way through, and the nut fit was very tight. So I created a new version that is just like his, but that fixes these two problems. I've also uploaded an IGES file for those with 3D CAD programs that can edit and modify such files.

This fits over the Printrbot's 5/16 threaded rod. Use two 5/16 18 nuts (one on the bottom and one on the top) to hold this in place so you can use the knob to turn the threaded rod without slipping.  
I recommend using Kisslicer with support material to slice this model. I've had problems with Slic3r on both this model, and also with owens' model.

title: Mushroom Salt and Pepper Shaker Set

description.text: Intro and Purpose
Inspired by a real world ceramic mushroom salt and pepper shaker set, these were created as a cheap plastic alternative.
Use

Fill red mushroom (3 holes on top) with salt. Then cap with included cap. Cap may need to be resized depending on the quality of your prints. Results may vary. Repeat for green mushroom, but with pepper.

Change List
--
  • V1: Initial release, untested

50% 1 shell for both mushrooms. Print as they would be on table (pouring holes up!)  
For mushrooms optimally you need 3 colors per. For red, use white filament till underside, switch to black or grey, then when cap starts to form, switch to red. For green do exact same, but end with green instead of red. The final image shows how to do this.   
10% 1 shell for caps. Print caps small diameter down, do that the knob is at the top.

Old Volvos never die, but you might die of thirst inside one!  Here is a clip on cup holder for a Volvo 240.  The clips hold onto the little tray above the hazard light/cigarette lighter/air con switch.  It's intentionally a tight fit and needs a little persistence, patience, and force to get them into place - I find that pushing a thumb into the curved bottom edge of the tray while forcing the clip to rotate into position does the trick.  I'm not sure that makes sense, so am very happy to expand on it if anyone needs clarification.  The clips are pretty tough, so I had no problems getting them into place once I overcame my fears that I'd snap them.

I printed with triple shells, 0.27mm layers, 10% infil, printed flat.  On a prototype I printed the clips vertically, but the layers delaminated too easily when being attached, so a flat print is much stronger and I've eliminated overhangs.  I also assembled the cup holder before installing into the car, but I suppose you could put it together after the clips have been seated... but that seems trickier to me than getting two clips on simultaneously since the tabs are a pretty tight fit.

description.text: Race car body - add legos to complete it!  I made this up as a party favor for my son's 6th birthday party, which we had at a race track.  His one featured his initials and his age on the sides of the car, but I've blanked those areas out for you (you can use your fav. 3D tool to add your own text!)

  • Lego steering wheel, 2-stud base, 1x per car
  • Lego driver, 1x per car
  • Lego 2x2 base plates, 0x - 2x per car to improve fit of steering wheel and driver if needed

author: jarda956

description.text: Miniature Carousel. A miniature carousel designed using Sketchup8 (free version), and printed with both Makerware and ReplicatorG on a MakerBot Replicator2. The design is very tolerant of low infill and single shell printing, thus minimizing plastic consumption as well as build time. I've now built four of these, two using Makerware, and two using ReplicatorG. While ReplicatorG did a slightly better job, Makerware was slightly faster. Both worked, albeit with some additional trimming using a modeling knife with the Makerware print. The first photo is of the Makerware version at .15 layer height and 1 shell. The second photo is of the Makerware version at default medium print settings. As can be seen, decreasing the layer height from the Makerware default medium print settings layer height of .27 to .15 improves the looks, however the build time is increased. Video of prototype at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0wqBTI5HUPs.

1) Carefully examine Carousel.skp. You will need to print 6 Flag.stl (well, you do not really need the flags, but the wife wanted them, so if you do too, then print one for each horse and one for the top of Canopy.stl), 5 Horse.stl, 1 Base.stl, 1 Bottom.stl, 1 Top.stl and 1 Canopy.stl. Print your parts in the color(s) of your choice then assemble following the Carousel.skp diagram. 2) Buy this motor: 6VDC 45 RPM Pinky Finger Sized Gear Motor 1" Long x 15/32" x 3/8" from either amazon.com or directly from http://sciplus.com/p/MICROMOTOR_47952 (this is the same motor I used in the Marbelvator design). In this application, I run the motor at 1.5 VDC and as such the motor requires 10 to 20 ma to run which is suitable for a small power supply, battery and/or solar panel use. Solder the obligatory red and black wires (about 4 inches each) to the motor plus and minus terminals respectively. Slide the motor into Base.stl, wires first, such that the motor wire terminals are parallel with the large rectangle at the bottom of Base.stl. Route the wires through the wire trough on the bottom of Base.stl. If you cannot find a 1.5 VDC power supply, use a 3 VDC power supply and use two 1N4007 diodes (or equivalent) to reduce the voltage. 3) I found if you print using Makerware, you will need to trim the flag staff and horse insert with a modeling knife. 4) It is helpful to test fit the motor output shaft on Top.stl before assembly. Make sure the motor shaft flat aligns with the flat in the hole in Top.stl before insertion. 5) If you have questions, place a comment and I'll try my best to answer them.

comments.text: The output shaft of the motor is inserted into a hole in the center of the underside of Top.stl.  Bottom.stl is attached to Top.stl via the 5 vertical supports.  When the shaft rotates, Top.stl and Bottom.stl thus rotate together.  Canopy.stl is for decoration and just goes along for the ride.

description.text: This is a replacement mount for the ikea cheap worklights. One I bought didn't come with one so I copied another and printed it. Enjoy! I have also attached the SW2012 file. http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/20370383/ Inspired by Sweedish Meatballs.
Don't print it like a dummy.

author: AcademyFab

description.text: A high detail model of the US Air force B1 Bomber AKA Lancer. It has been thickened up across the wings and tail and sliced in half to enable easy successful printing. Each half is a single solid shell ready to print. This is a new version, slightly thickened and internal geometry removed. This should stop the errors/failed prints that people were getting!

description.text: Stephen Colbert is no thug -- but thanks to the magic of 3D modeling, his head joins a strong tradition of physical mashups in the T-verse: the Gangsta mashups. I replaced the head of yzorg's Gangsta model (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5367) as cleaned up by cibomahto (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6891) with "The Head of Stephen Colbert by Colbert" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9104).

I printed this out with some experimental Support settings (in Skeinforge: Raft) activated -- the model turned out really great. I suspect that you can print him without support:  I can't wait to give him a try.

I have a CNC machine that I built from http://buildyourcnc.com/book.aspx. Well it was in my basement for a couple years but never really used it because; 1. debris got everywhere, and 2. it was loud! So This weekend I brought it up into the garage where I will keep it (maybe it will get more use.) As right now, it is sitting on the ground, and when I want to mill something, I am going to want to put it outside onto the driveway. But it's heavy!! So I ran to Walmart and found some 2" swivel casters. (I was going to print my own casters but didn't have much time on my side) Now I will be able to roll it out onto the driveway! I knew I had to make something to allow the caster to mount to my CNC stand ends. That is where I came up with this design. I made the holes smaller to be able to tap them. Designed to rest underneath the CNC itself, I added a bolt to secure the mount(1/4-20).

What you need PER caster:
1- 1/4-20 nut
1- 1/4-20 x 1.5 hex screw
4- M6-16 socket head cap screw (1.25 pitch)
1- 2" swivel caster 1/4-20 tap
M6-1.25 tap Print model (I'm going with 35% infill)
Tap the 4 caster holes with a M6-1.25 tap.
Tap the nut insert side hole with a 1/4-20 tap.
Carefully press the 1/4-20 nut in place.

description.text:
ANNOUNCEMENT!!

The files for this model have been removed from this page, from now on the files can downloaded for free from www.MyMiniFactory.com. This page will be left for legacy purposes and I will still answer questions if posted.

From now on, all my future projects will feature exclusively on www.MyMiniFactory.com.
My profile page is https://www.myminifactory.com/users/lilykill.

Sorry for any inconvenience.

Here is the new Laser Pistol from Fallout 4 which was shown off in Bethesda's E3 conference.

Currently, this is only a solid STL as I'm still modifying the assembly but the final assembly will consist of roughly 40 parts and have a working Microfusion Cell reload mechanism. I have created the assembly in such a way that the mods that you can have on the pistol are interchangeable.

The current mods I have planned for the assembly;
Short Scope
Reflex Sight
Tactical Grip
Beam Splitter
Beam Focuser

If you want a Fallout fix, check out my other Fallout props;
http://www.thingiverse.com/lilykill/collections/fallout-props

Happy Printing and just remember, Tunnel Snakes Rule!

Follow me on twitter @ https://twitter.com/lilykill1, and instagram @ https://instagram.com/lilykill1/ and facebook @ https://www.facebook.com/Lilykill-253119598353137/ where you can stay up-to-date on my current projects and releases.

Update 24/07/15
I have modelled some of the mods as shown off in the new render.
Once I've settled on the tolerances and printed the assembly so it fits together nicely then Ill release the files.

Update 19/08/15
Part files have now been uploaded as a .rar file. I haven't printed this yet but I know loads of you have waited long enough to print this yourselves.

Update 29/08/15
Forgot to upload 1 part ('GEARED SLIDE') for the reload mechanism.

Update 23/10/15
Uploaded a pic of my build so far, I will adjust the fits on the model and upload again once I'm done.

14/01/16
2D layout with dimensions added. Scale is 1:1 at A1, Reference dimensions added to help.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Resolution and infill can vary on the size or strength need from each item. My average settings were; 0.5mm nozzle, 0.2mm layers, 15% infill.

Items such as the ribs that make up the underneath of the main body of the gun and the dowel I went as far as 40-50% so that I didn't comprise any strength after sanding.

Pre-processing before Painting

All the dowels that make up the main body of the gun will be very tight or may not fit initially, I had done this is so that the connecting dowels can be finely sanded down. This allows a very tight fit and will give the best connection strength possible when glued as this is a very nose heavy weapon.

description.text:
This is a cube (the name I choose was blackbox as the box used in physic research), printed on a 10 cm side length (about 4") is a labyrinth. Used with a metal ball (20 mm - 4/5") you must go from the front door to the back one. Sure it's harder that you think !

Ce cube, nommé "blackbox" comme l'outil utilisé par les physiciens dans la recherche nucléeaire... (une particule entre, va-t-elle sortir mais où ?) est imprimé à une taille de 10 cm de côté. En placant une bille de métal (ou autre) de 20 mm de diamètre, le but est de la faire sortir de l'autre côté, en aveugle. Plus dur qu'il n'y paraît. Seule la sensation des mouvements de la bille et les sons vous guident.

Upgraded version of x-carriage for Sunhokey Prusa i3 2015-edition.

It requires 2 extra pieces of SC8UU and is ment to be used with E3D-V6 hot-end full kit.

It is made to maximize Z-axe travel.

Included fanduct mounts to the main carriage by tapped M3 holes using M3 bolts.

Belt is attached to M4 bolts mounted on the back using middle holes.

Final version in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cVUZgJtGpjE
Previous version (beta testing)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pRYsodeik0A
I printed on 0.3 and 0.25 height - both worked great. Print without support. Can be printed with PLA.

Pi case for the Raspi 2. Stackable, wall mountable, printable with single extruder... see instructions. Enjoy!

Note: the pins in the top part will probably break off, so be prepared to have some M2x5 screws about, though these are not 100% necessary. The portrusion from the top is enough to ensure the pis position.

Feedback and constructiive critiscism welcome.

This is a Mosaic with substrate. I used a piece of masonite as the board. The thought is that you can just print the moasic, glue or mortar it to a board/wall/ etc.... then grout it. simple as that. oh, and I hot glued some neodymium magnets to the back of mine to make it into a refrigerator magnet.

1) print mosaic  
2) cut a board or select surface to affix mosaic to (i used masonite)  
3) mortar or use adhesive to attach mosaic to surface  
4) grout I used non sanded white grout to go with the blue pla I used.
